According to the policy document, a life insurance policy can be transferred or assigned as per Section 38 of the Insurance Act, 1938. The process involves specific requirements and procedures.

* A transferor or assignor must sign the assignment, and it should be attested by at least one witness.
* A notice in writing with fee must be delivered to the insurer, along with either the endorsement or instrument itself or a certified copy of both.
* The priority of claims of persons interested in an insurance policy would depend on the date on which the notices of assignment or transfer is delivered to the insurer.

**Nomination by Policyholder**

A life insurance policyholder may nominate one or more persons to receive the policy's payout in the event of their death. This nomination can be made at any time before the policy matures.

* The nominee(s) will receive the share of the amount secured under the policy upon the policyholder's death.
* If a nominee dies after the policyholder but before receiving payment, their share will be paid to their heirs or legal representative.

**Policy Not Being Called in Question**

According to Section 45 of the Insurance Act, 1938, as amended by the Insurance Laws (Amendment) Act, 2015, a life insurance policy cannot be questioned on any ground after three years from its issuance or commencement of risk, unless it is a case of fraud.
